0.name: Data Structure
0.description: A specialized format in the management, organization and storage of data for efficient access to them.

1.name: Discrete Structure
1.description: The study of discrete mathematical structures in computer science.

2.name: Algorithms
2.description: A finite sequence of rigorous instruction used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation.

3.name: Computer Systems
3.description: A complex interconnection of the computer's operating system/hardware and software which work together to provide computing capabilities.

4.name: Performance
4.description: The efficiency and speed of a computer system or application in terms of executing tasks and managing resources—encompassing speed, throughput, latency, and resource utilization.

5.name: Design Patterns
5.description: General, formalized, and reusable descriptions or templates of solutions that can be used to solve common problems when designing an application or system.

6.name: Efficiency
6.description: A property of an algorithm which relates to the amount of the computational resources it uses.

7.name: Higher-Order Programming
7.description: A style that heavily utilizes software components as higher-order functions*, borrowing concepts from models of computations such as lambda calculus; *a function that takes one or more functions as arguments, or returns a function as its result.

8.name: Cleanliness
8.description: The quality of readability and maintainability of the source code in a software project.

9.name: Optimization
9.description: The process of modifying a software system so that the work uses fewer resources, executes more rapidly, operates with less memory storage, or draws less power.

10.name: Frameworks & Integrations
10.description: An abstraction providing a standard of particular functionality to facilitate the development of software applications, products, and solutions.

11.name: Dynamic Programming
11.description: A mathematical and algorithmic optimization method where complicated problems are broken down into simpler sub-problems in a recursive manner.

12.name: Asynchronous Programming
12.description: A technique that enables a program to start a new task while allowing the program to still be responsive to other events, and not having the program to wait for the old task to finish.

13.name: Maintainability
13.description: Advanced concept of efficient code development that improves readability, coupling, or consistency of the code.

14.name: Profiling
14.description: A form of dynamic program analysis that measures the space or time complexity of a program, the usage of particular instructions, or the frequency and duration of function calls.

15.name: Debugging
15.description: The process of finding and resolving bugs—defects or problems that prevent correct operations—within computer programs, software, or systems.

16.name: Responsiveness
16.description: The adaptability of the design in different environments, especially in a web development.

17.name: Software Architecture
17.description: The set of structures needed to reason about a software system and the discipline of creating such structures and systems.

18.name: Automation
18.description: A technique of programming a script or a batch processing that allows repetitive tasks to save time, reduce effort, and perform complex and tedious operations.

19.name: Modular Programming
19.description: A software design technique emphasizing on separating the functionality of a program into independent, interchangable modules such that each contains everything necessary to execute only one aspect of the desired functionality.

20.name: Version Control
20.description: The practice of tracking and managing changes to computer programs and software code.

21.name: Monitoring
21.description: The process of observing and collecting data from software applications, systems, or networks to ensure their proper functioning, performance, and security.

22.name: Scalability
22.description: A software development practice towards a system's ability to increase in performance and decrease in cost with its changes in its application and system processing demands.

23.name: Networking
23.description: A software development technique of writing programs or processes that can communicate with other programs or processes across a network.

24.name: Cloud Computing
24.description: An on-demand access, via the internet, to computing resources—applications, physical and virtual servers, data storage, development tools, networking capabilities, and more—hosted at a remote data center managed by a cloud services provider.

25.name: Systems Design
25.description: The process of defining and developing the architecture, components, modules, interfaces, and data for a system to satisfy the specified requirements of the user.

26.name: Scripting
26.description: A way of delivering instructions that automates various step-by-step functions or processes to a computer as with all forms of programming.

27.name: Software Testing
27.description: The act of examining the artifacts and the behavior of the software under test by validation and verification.

28.name: Software Analysis
28.description: A requirement analysis that aims to gain insights of behavior, performance, and structure by techniques such as code, data, and algorithms examinations.

29.name: Data Handling
29.description: Techniques of recording, collecting, and representing data that is presented into valuable insights or actionable information.

30.name: Software Security
30.description: The concept of implementing security mechanisms to protect software applications and digital solutions from attackers.

31.name: Software Engineering
31.description: An engineering-based approach to design, develop, test, maintain, and evaluate computer software.

32.name: Distributed Computing
32.description: A method of developing a system whose components are located on different networked computers, which communicate and coordinate their actions by passing messages to one another.

33.name: Usability
33.description: A programming technique that allows a software or code to be used by specified consumers with effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction in a quantified context of its use.

34.name: CI/CD
34.description: The combined practice of continuous integration (frequent merging of several small changes into a main branch) and continuous delivery (the rapid and reliable software release).

35.name: Big Data
35.description: Organization, administration, and governance of large volumes of both structured and unstructured data.

36.name: Ethical Hacking
36.description: Ethical act of identifying any vulnerabilities or security issues the current system has with the aim to improve upon its security.

37.name: Computer Graphics
37.description: A sub-field of computer science which studies methods for digitally synthesizing and manipulating visual content.

38.name: Cryptography
38.description: the practice and study of techniques for a secure communication in the presence of an adversarial behavior.

39.name: Research
39.description: The systematic investigation into and study of materials, sources, etc, in order to establish facts and reach new conclusions.

40.name: Artificial Intelligence
40.description: A field of study in computer science that develops and studies intelligent machines.

41.name: Game Design
41.description: The software development of video games by the creation of the mechanics, systems, and its rules.

42.name: Computer Vision
42.description: The methods for acquiring, processing, analyzing, and understanding digital images along with the extraction of high-dimensional data from the real world in order to produce numerical or symbolic information.

43.name: Data Science
43.description: An interdisciplinary academic field that uses statistics, scientific computing and methods, processes, algorithms and systems to extract or extrapolate knowledge and insights from potentially noisy, structured, or unstructured data.

44.name: Deep Learning
44.description: The subset of machine learning methods based on artificial neural networks with representation learning.

45.name: Simulation
45.description: The process of modeling a real phenomenon with a set of mathematical formulas.

46.name: VR/AR
46.description: The use of computer modeling and simulation that enables a person to interact with an artificial three-dimensional visual or other sensory environment.

47.name: Advanced Topics
47.description: Subjects, themes, or areas of study that are characterized by a higher level of complexity, depth, and specialization.
